transcripts.text: I need some direction.  Ms.  Bassey is here, and Ms.  Bassey is being Ms.  Bassey, and I caught her on camera turning on her camera slash video function on her iPad.  I can't confirm she's not recording or not, but she is acting very Ms.  Bassey-like.  If you can please give me a call, we can get some direction from you, what you want me to do.  I'd be really appreciated.  Okay, thank you very much.

This is Susan Bassey, and it's hard to know who to trust these days and where you can get reliable information.  Many of our government institutions look and feel as we've known all of our lives, and yet when we go to try to use the services that we believe we should be afforded, we find that they are not operating the way that they should.

You can call the 800 number and complain to the governor, but that's just the way it is.  That's the law.  So we're not lying.  That's the law.  Where is that law?  Where is that law?  I don't know.  You have to call the governor and ask him.  I just want to know what law is saying that this is open till five and people can't come in.
So we're open till five, but we all have to be out of here by five p.m.
period.  So we're not allowing any walk-ins after 4 p.m So that sounds like a policy that you guys...
And you can go to any DMV and it's going to be the same way.

Okay, but that sounds like a policy, not a law.  Is that right?  Yeah, maybe a policy.  You can get the contact then.  We don't make up the rules.  We're just the workers.  Well, if you're making a policy, you're making up the rules.
No, I don't make the policies.
Who made the policy?

The higher up people.  Okay, well, the higher up people that made that policy, you're up until five.  Your website says you're taking walk-ins.  We want to walk in.  Where does it say we're taking walk-ins?  Where's your supervisor?  We want to talk to your supervisor.  Actually, we're going to have to come back Monday morning.  No, I'd like to speak with the supervisor.  Who is the supervisor?  Shelly.

First Amendment auditors and cop watchers on YouTube taught me that when a police officer doesn't know the law and is violating your rights, that you need to ask for a supervisor.  And so in this case, when I had a DMV worker telling me what the law and the policy was and preventing me from entering the DMV during normal business hours, I asked to speak for a supervisor.  And suddenly, the policy about me not being able to go in after 4 o'clock got changed to be done in there and out by five.
Why you can't let the two of us in?  Nope, because then we would have to let everybody in.
Well, then the website should say we're not taking people after four o'clock.

I agree with you too.  If I would have made the website, I would have put that on there too.  Yeah, well, you guys can't just make up policies to bypass the law and what taxpayers are paying to have open.  Well, that's great.  All of us, we're all taxpayers.

So apparently the policy that existed two minutes earlier no longer existed and a supervisor was going to speak with me.  Again, I asked for a supervisor based on what I learned from the First Amendment auditors.
No, I don't, sir.  Are you a police officer?  You cannot record people.
You can't be doing that.
I'm in public.
But you cannot record people.
I'm a reporter.  I know the law.
But you can't record people.
You can't record me.  So you can't be doing that.  So why is he recording people for?
What would you like to do?
If you can just shut it off, that would be good.  I don't know why you recorded me.
Do you not know the law about recording in public?
That's for something tragic.  There's nothing tragic going on over here.

This was perhaps the most interesting response that I had ever had to an issue of recording in a public building, a DMV.  This was a private security guard, and he actually told me that you were allowed to record when there was something tragic happening.  And I think many people these days don't understand that recording in public is not a selective issue.  You have a right to do it at all times.  There is, actually.

Like what?  Well, first of all, you're pulling your mask down.  And second of all, I'm in a DMV that advertised it was open until 5, and it wasn't letting people in.  So I'm documenting it.  Document whatever you want.
It don't matter.  You need to turn that off.  Period.
I'm recording it.
But we are closed as far as for appointment and also for non-appointment that walking in at 4.30.
But this sounds like a policy that you're putting in place.  It's not the law.  The law says that you're open until 5.
It is a policy and it's on the website.  So if you check the website, I can pull it up and share with you.
I would like to see where that is.

But right now, if your license is 5... You can come back, upload your application and everything, and we will service you as an appointment.  And that before 4 o'clock.  Okay?  So right now, 438, we can't service you.  So let me go get that information for you, especially if you don't have an appointment.
Okay?  What is your name?  Tina.
Tina.  Thank you.
I'll be right back.  I'd like to know where it is on the website.  No.  You know what?  I can see it.
So here's this website and this is what it shows.  Sally, you have a copy of a central transaction?

Where does it say that nobody's being let in until 4?  You have a copy of something that shows a central transaction.  So did you get it down at the PDF or are you trying to print it?  What do you mean?  a central transaction?  Meaning the service that we provide them to come in will have that.  You guys didn't provide all that information.  It's not there.  And don't send money because that's something that you didn't receive.

You can download the statement of facts.  It's a second form on the bottom right there.  Download the statement of facts and make your statement.  At the time that I made this video, there was a state order issued by Governor Gavin Newsom in response to COVID-19 that everybody indoors had to wear a mask.  That includes the workers.  The worker in the background here was not wearing his mask.  People were also required to social distance, and I often found these workers were not six feet apart.
Yeah, there's nothing on here that says you don't take people after four.  I don't see that.  Can you show me that?
Okay, here's the thing.
I'm looking because I'm informing the public so nobody else comes down here after four.  So show me where it says that.
Okay, this is how we translate.  The DMV will provide service by appointment only.
You heard that correctly.  The Department of Motor Vehicles, a state agency in California under the jurisdiction of Governor Newsom,
